__data__.text: In the early years of radio broadcasting, the first stations were WEAF and WJZ. Radio Corporation of America (RCA) acquired WEAF from American Telephone & Telegraph (AT&T) during a phase of radio industry consolidation. WJZ, originally owned by Westinghouse, was transferred to RCA and moved to New York City. WEAF served as a research and development center for AT&T's manufacturing division, Western Electric, which produced transmitters and antennas. The Bell System, AT&T's telephone utility, was working on technology to transmit high-quality audio over short and long distances. WEAF began regular broadcasting, including commercial programs, and quickly became popular.

In 1922, WEAF was established as a research and development center for radio technology and began regular broadcasting, including commercial programs, rapidly gaining popularity. It initiated "chain" or "networking" broadcasting by connecting with other stations. RCA, WEAF's parent company, attempted to transmit audio between cities using low-quality telegraph lines, but faced challenges due to interference. In 1925, AT&T, which owned high-quality phone lines, decided to sell WEAF and its network to RCA, granting RCA the right to lease AT&T's phone lines for network transmission. This sale led to the creation of the Red and Blue Networks. WJZ also played a role in this development, originally owned by Westinghouse, then transferred to RCA and moved to New York City.

In 1925, AT&T sold WEAF and its network to RCA, allowing RCA to lease AT&T's high-quality phone lines for network transmission. RCA, along with General Electric and Westinghouse, then established the National Broadcasting Company (NBC) in 1926, investing $1 million to acquire WEAF and WCAP, before merging their facilities and shutting down WCAP. NBC was divided into two networks: the "Red Network," which featured commercially sponsored entertainment and music, and the "Blue Network," which mostly broadcast non-sponsored programs such as news and cultural events. NBC officially began broadcasting in November 1926, with WEAF and WJZ operating side by side for a year before formally dividing their marketing strategies on January 1, 1927.

NBC, established in 1926 by RCA, General Electric, and Westinghouse, initially consisted of two networks: the Red Network, offering commercial entertainment and music, and the Blue Network, broadcasting non-sponsored programs like news and cultural events. The color designations possibly originated from the use of red and blue pushpins or pencils to mark affiliate stations. NBC expanded to the West Coast in 1927 with the Orange Network (Pacific Coast Network), carrying Red Network programming, and the Gold Network (Pacific Gold Network), broadcasting Blue Network content. Initially, the Orange Network recreated Eastern Red Network programming for West Coast stations, but in 1936, Orange Network affiliates merged with the Red Network and the Gold Network became part of the Blue Network. NBC's headquarters moved to 711 Fifth Avenue in Manhattan in 1927.

In the 1930s, NBC expanded its networks to include shortwave radio stations (NBC White Network) and outgrew its Fifth Avenue headquarters by 1933, moving to the Rockefeller Center, with RCA becoming the lead tenant at the "RCA Building" (now Comcast Building). This move followed General Electric's antitrust-related divestment from RCA in 1930, with GE's Owen D. Young and RCA's David Sarnoff negotiating the deal with John D. Rockefeller Jr. The iconic NBC chimes, with the sequence G-E-C', were first aired over Red Network affiliate WSB in Atlanta.

In the 1930s, NBC's chimes (G-E'-C') were first aired over WSB, an affiliate of the Red Network, and later adopted by NBC's national network. These chimes, with a C-major triad outline, were mechanized in 1932 by Rangertone founder Richard H. Ranger for system cueing. A four-note sequence, including an additional G, was used during significant events like World War II and disasters. The chimes became the first audio trademark registered by the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office. This innovation followed NBC's expansion to shortwave radio stations and relocation to the Rockefeller Center due to GE's divestment from RCA.

In the 1930s, NBC introduced their iconic three-note chimes (G-E'-C'), which were initially mechanized for system cueing and later became the first audio trademark registered by the US Patent and Trademark Office. Contrary to popular belief, the notes did not originally represent General Electric. The chimes are still used by the NBC television network, including NBC News. The Blue Network separated from NBC and became ABC in 1938. During this time, the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) investigated NBC and CBS for monopolistic practices due to Mutual Broadcasting System's difficulties establishing new radio stations. This marked the beginning of regulatory scrutiny over network broadcasting.

In 1938, the FCC launched investigations into the monopolistic impact of network broadcasting, culminating in a 1939 report that highlighted NBC's dominance in audiences, affiliates, and advertising. The FCC ordered RCA to sell either NBC Red or NBC Blue, which led to RCA selling NBC Blue to Dillon, Read & Co. in 1942 after its appeal was denied. The Blue Network was then renamed Blue Network Company, Inc. and operated independently from NBC Red, which became simply known as NBC on-air. This divestiture was a result of regulatory scrutiny over network broadcasting, which began with the FCC's investigation into NBC and CBS's monopolistic practices.

After RCA was forced to sell NBC Blue due to regulatory scrutiny, Dillon, Read & Co. initially placed a $7.5 million bid, which was rejected. Ultimately, RCA sold NBC Blue to the American Broadcasting System (ABS), owned by Edward J. Noble, for $8 million. The sale included the Blue Network name, leases on landlines, New York studios, two-and-a-half radio stations, contracts with actors, and agreements with around 60 affiliates. Noble had to sell his existing New York City radio station, WMCA, to comply with FCC radio station ownership limits. Post-sale, the Blue Network became known as Blue Network Company, Inc., and NBC Red was simply called NBC on-air.

Following the sale of NBC Blue to Edward J. Noble's American Broadcasting System (ABS), Noble complied with FCC ownership limits by selling WMCA radio station. Renaming the network to "American Broadcasting Company" in 1944, ABC officially began operations on June 15, 1945. Meanwhile, NBC became a popular network, hosting renowned performers and programs, including Bing Crosby, Jack Benny, and Arturo Toscanini's NBC Symphony Orchestra. Noble played a role in acquiring the "American Broadcasting Company" name and ABC featured various popular shows during radio's golden age.

In the mid-1940s, ABC, formerly NBC Blue, initiated its operations, offering popular shows such as Vic and Sade, Fibber McGee and Molly, The Great Gildersleeve, One Man's Family, Ma Perkins, and Death Valley Days. Meanwhile, NBC, with its powerful stations and unique clear-channel frequencies, showcased famous talents like Bing Crosby, Jack Benny, and Arturo Toscanini's NBC Symphony Orchestra. During the late 1940s, CBS gained popularity by enabling radio stars to create programs through their production companies, leading to a shift of NBC stars, including Jack Benny, Edgar Bergen and Charlie McCarthy, Burns and Allen, and Frank Sinatra, to CBS. NBC talent also started moving to television, with Milton Berle's Texaco Star Theater becoming television's first major hit and Arturo Toscanini conducting NBC Symphony Orchestra concerts on both television and radio, marking the first simulcasting instance.

In the late 1940s and early 1950s, as television gained popularity, NBC made efforts to keep classic radio alive and compete with CBS's successful radio lineup. They achieved a milestone in simulcasting by airing Arturo Toscanini's NBC Symphony Orchestra concerts on both television and radio, featuring historic performances of Beethoven's Symphony No. 9 and Verdi's Aida. In response to CBS's success, NBC introduced The Big Show in 1950, a 90-minute variety program led by Tallulah Bankhead and featuring renowned entertainers. Despite critical acclaim, the show's popularity waned due to the growing number of television viewers.

After The Big Show's initial success with prestigious guests like Ella Fitzgerald, its popularity declined due to the growing number of television viewers, resulting in NBC losing approximately $1 million. In response, NBC introduced Monitor in 1955, a continuous weekend radio program with various hosts, including TV personalities Dave Garroway, Hugh Downs, Ed McMahon, Joe Garagiola, and Gene Rayburn. Monitor aimed to maintain traditional radio by incorporating popular segments from Jim and Marian Jordan (as Fibber McGee and Molly), Peg Lynch's Ethel and Albert, and satirist Henry Morgan.

Monitor, a successful NBC radio program featuring various hosts and popular segments, maintained traditional radio during the decline in listeners in the 1950s and 1960s. However, local stations, particularly in larger markets, became reluctant to run non-conforming network programming. NBC then launched NIS, a 24/7 news service, in 1975, but discontinued it shortly after due to profitability concerns. By the end of the 1970s, NBC network radio primarily consisted of hourly newscasts, news features, and The Eternal Light.

In the late 1970s, NBC launched NIS, a 24/7 news service, which attracted several dozen subscribing stations but was discontinued due to profitability concerns. Following this, NBC introduced The Source, a secondary network that supplied news and short features to FM rock stations, achieving moderate success. Simultaneously, NBC Radio Network initiated a satellite-distributed evening talk show, TalkNet, offering personal advice in various aspects of life. Although TalkNet never gained significant ratings, it contributed to the development of national talk radio and assisted affiliates, mainly struggling AM stations, in filling evening time slots with free programming for local advertising. This trend raised concerns in the industry about increasing network and syndicator control over radio content.

In the late 1970s, NBC established NIS and later The Source and TalkNet, which, despite not gaining significant ratings, contributed to the growth of national talk radio and helped affiliates fill evening time slots with free programming. This trend raised concerns about increasing network control over radio content. When GE reacquired RCA in 1985, it decided to sell NBC's radio holdings. Westwood One, a California-based syndicator, bought NBC Radio Network, The Source, TalkNet, and NBC Radio Entertainment for $50 million, equivalent to $129 million in 2022. This acquisition included leases to the radio network's facilities and led to further consolidation, with NBC Radio News moving to Mutual's Arlington, Virginia, facility and both networks jointly producing newscasts in overnights and weekends. The radio stations were sold off to various companies, including Emmis Communications, Westinghouse, and Susquehanna Radio Corporation.

In 1992, Mutual and NBC news broadcasts started being jointly produced during overnights and weekends, and both networks began airing shared generic sports updates throughout the weekend. Westwood One's acquisition of Unistar Radio Networks from Infinity Broadcasting in 1994 allowed Infinity to purchase 25% of Westwood One, becoming its largest shareholder and gaining control. Later, Infinity was acquired by Westinghouse Electric Corporation (which later merged with CBS/Westinghouse Broadcasting) for $5 billion in 1996, bringing CBS Radio Network under Westwood One management. The Mutual/NBC newsroom in Arlington closed in 1998, with CBS Radio News producing "Mutual" and "NBC" newscasts from New York. By 1999, these "NBC"-branded newscasts were limited to weekday morning drive (ET), and Westwood One officially retired the Mutual name. This series of events represents further consolidation in the radio industry during this period.

In 1999, "NBC"-branded newscasts produced by CBS were limited to weekday morning drive (ET), and remaining NBC affiliates were offered CNN Radio newscasts at other times. Westwood One retired the Mutual name and partnered with NBC News to launch NBC News Radio in 2003, featuring one-minute newscasts on weekdays. An audio simulcast of Meet the Press was also distributed by Westwood One. In 2011, Westwood One was merged into Dial Global, which ended distribution of CNN Radio newscasts and made NBC News Radio a full-time operation in 2012. NBC Sports Radio was launched that same year as a joint venture between Dial Global and NBC Sports. This series of events represents further consolidation in the radio industry and a shift towards NBC-branded programming.

NBC Sports Radio was launched as a joint venture between Dial Global and NBC Sports in 2011, but it ceased 24/7 programming in 2018 and shut down in 2020. Dial Global, which had acquired Westwood One and merged it into Cumulus Media Networks, ended NBC News Radio in 2014 after striking a content-sharing deal with CNN. Currently, iHeartMedia produces NBC News Radio-branded newscasts under a licensing agreement with NBCUniversal. Historically, NBC was associated with David Sarnoff, who utilized the network to promote consumer electronics, including the introduction of all-electronic television at the 1939-40 New York World's Fair.

In 1939, as part of NBC's promotion of consumer electronics, President Franklin D. Roosevelt made the first US presidential television appearance on NBC's W2XBS Channel 1, which was transmitted from the Empire State Building and viewed by around 1,000 people. The next day, RCA began selling television sets in department stores, following NBC's announced television launch. It's worth noting that DuMont Laboratories had already introduced home sets in 1938. This all took place in the context of NBC's history, which was associated with David Sarnoff, who used the network to promote consumer electronics.

DuMont Laboratories and other companies had introduced home television sets in 1938, preceding NBC's official television launch in April 1939. Following the launch, NBC began broadcasting at professional sports games in the New York City area and established several "firsts" in television broadcasting. The first NBC Television "network" program, Meet The Wife, was broadcast in January 1940 and rebroadcast in Schenectady. Occasional special events were also aired in Philadelphia and Schenectady. The most notable NBC television "network" program before the war was the live telecast of the Republican National Convention in Philadelphia in the summer of 1940, which was transmitted to the New York City and Schenectady stations. All of these events were part of NBC's history of promoting consumer electronics, under the leadership of David Sarnoff.

From 1939 to 1942, television sales in New York were modest due to high set costs and limited programming. Only a few thousand sets were sold, many going to public places for viewing special events. One notable event was President Franklin D. Roosevelt's live television appearance at Madison Square Garden in October 1940. Following the FCC's authorization of commercial television broadcasts in July 1941, NBC's W2XBS in New York became WNBT, the first U.S. station to air a paid advertisement, featuring Bulova watches before a Brooklyn Dodgers game. This marked the conclusion of television's experimental phase. These events are part of NBC's history of fostering consumer electronics under David Sarnoff's leadership.

The first official paid television advertisement in the U.S. was aired by watch manufacturer Bulova on WNBT, before a Brooklyn Dodgers game. The ad was a test pattern with functioning hands and the Bulova logo. WNBT's first commercial week included shows like The Sunoco News, amateur boxing, tennis championships, USO programming, Words on the Wing, films, and a special broadcast of Truth or Consequences. Non-paid television advertising had existed experimentally since the 1930s. These events are part of NBC's history under David Sarnoff's leadership.

Under David Sarnoff's leadership, NBC's initial non-paid television commercials might have been presented during the first broadcast of a Major League Baseball game between the Brooklyn Dodgers and Cincinnati Reds in 1939. Dodgers announcer Red Barber promoted various sponsors, such as Ivory Soap, Mobilgas, and Wheaties, by displaying products or wearing appropriate attire. Commercials were limited during this period, with telecasts decreasing at the start of World War II and gradually increasing as NBC readied for full-time service after the war.

Under Sarnoff's leadership, NBC started airing limited commercials during the first MLB game broadcast in 1939. Commercial programming was reduced during WWII, but NBC resumed expanding its telecasts in preparation for full-time service post-war. Notably, the first regularly scheduled program on NBC television network was The Voice of Firestone Televues, which began airing from New York to Philadelphia and Schenectady weekly in April 1944.

In 1944, "The War As It Happens" became the first news program regularly aired in multiple cities on the NBC Television Network, which initially consisted of three stations: New York, Schenectady, and Philadelphia. This was preceded by "The Voice of Firestone Televues" as the first regularly scheduled program on the network. Notably, on V-E Day in 1945, WNBT provided extensive news coverage and remotes from New York City, marking a significant event in television history. This broadcast, promoted through direct-mail to television set owners, showcased the network's capability for vivid coverage, contributing to its growth after the war.

The NBC television network experienced significant growth in the post-war 1940s and early 1950s, starting with just four stations and expanding through coaxial cable and transcontinental telecasts. The 1947 World Series, featuring two local teams, boosted television sales and audience engagement. Milton Berle emerged as television's first major star, drawing large audiences with Texaco Star Theatre. Under President Sylvester "Pat" Weaver, NBC introduced successful long-running shows like Today and The Tonight Show, which dominated the broadcast day for over 50 years.

During Sylvester "Pat" Weaver's tenure as NBC's president, the network introduced several groundbreaking shows, including the long-running Today and The Tonight Show, which dominated the broadcast day for over 50 years and continue to lead their competitors. Weaver also initiated periodic 90-minute network "spectaculars," network-produced motion pictures, and the live 90-minute Sunday afternoon series Wide Wide World. In 1951, NBC commissioned Italian-American composer Gian Carlo Menotti to write the first opera for television, Amahl and the Night Visitors, which aired annually on NBC until 1966, when a dispute between Menotti and NBC ended the broadcasts.

During Weaver's presidency at NBC, the network made significant strides in television, including the annual broadcast of Gian Carlo Menotti's opera Amahl and the Night Visitors from 1951 to 1966. However, a dispute between Menotti and NBC ended the annual broadcasts. In 1978, the two parties reconciled, and a new production of the opera was aired, partly filmed in the Middle East in color. Although CBS had initially broadcast color television programs, their system was incompatible with existing black and white sets, leading to its abandonment. RCA's compatible color system was then approved as the U.S. standard, and NBC was prepared with color programming soon after.

Under Weaver's presidency at NBC, the network quickly adopted RCA's compatible color system after the FCC approved it in December 1953. NBC started introducing color programming in 1954, with the first series to air all episodes in color, The Marriage, beginning in the summer of 1954. A notable broadcast was the live color telecast of Peter Pan, a new musical adaptation of J.M. Barrie's play, in 1955. This groundbreaking broadcast, part of the Producers' Showcase anthology series, featured the original cast, including Mary Martin as Peter and Cyril Ritchard as Mr. Darling and Captain Hook, and achieved the highest ratings for a television program during that time.

After the successful live color telecast of Peter Pan in 1955, which featured Mary Martin as Peter and Cyril Ritchard as Mr. Darling and Captain Hook and garnered the highest ratings for a TV program of that time, NBC restaged it in 1955 and 1960. In 1956, NBC established California National Productions (CNP) for merchandising, syndication, and opera company operations, and in 1957, CNP discussed syndication distribution for MGM series. Meanwhile, NBC's owned-and-operated station in Chicago, WNBQ, became the first TV station in the US to air color broadcasts daily by 1956.

In 1959, NBC introduced a color-televised version of The Bell Telephone Hour, which ran for nine more years. In 1961, NBC, with its advanced color broadcasting capabilities, secured the rights to Walt Disney's anthology series from ABC by offering to produce it in color. This was not possible for ABC due to its lack of color broadcasting resources, and as a result, Disney's series moved to NBC and began airing in color that same year. Many of the previously black-and-white Disney programs that had aired on ABC were already filmed in color, making the transition to NBC's color broadcasts seamless.

In 1962, NBC started airing colorized Disney programs that were originally filmed for ABC, leading to a smooth transition. The network's color capabilities were further highlighted by the 1962 Rose Bowl telecast, the first college football game in color. By 1963, a significant portion of NBC's prime time schedule was in color, though some shows like The Man from U.N.C.L.E. initially aired in black-and-white. By the fall of 1965, NBC, now known as "The Full Color Network," broadcast 95% of its prime time schedule in color, surpassing its competitors who only committed to an all-color lineup in the following season.

Rival networks were slower to adopt color broadcasting due to the lack of color TVs. They eventually committed to an all-color prime time lineup in the 1966-67 season. NBC, known as "The Full Color Network," had already started airing colorized Disney programs and college football games by 1962. They introduced the first soap opera in color, Days of Our Lives, in November 1965. NBC produced the first feature-length films for television in 1964, but only aired two before a two-year gap. In 1967, NBC acquired the broadcast rights to The Wizard of Oz from MGM, ending CBS's annual telecast of the film in color.

In the late 1960s, CBS and NBC engaged in a battle for broadcast rights of "The Wizard of Oz." CBS, which had aired the film annually in color since 1956, decided not to renew the rights due to increased fees. NBC, already known as "The Full Color Network," acquired the rights in 1967, making it one of the many color broadcasts on television. NBC's version was unique as it aired without a hosted introduction and was slightly edited for commercials, yet still maintained high ratings. From 1968 to 1976, NBC aired the film annually, leading CBS to reacquire the rights in 1977, recognizing their mistake in letting go of a successful program. This period marked a shift in programming practices for major television networks.

As baby boomers reached adulthood in the late 1960s and early 1970s, major networks like NBC, CBS, and ABC recognized the need to target younger audiences, who were attractive to advertisers. These networks began to phase out long-running shows that appealed to older viewers, focusing on adults aged 18-49, with possible subdivisions into other age demographics. NBC, for instance, canceled shows like "The Bell Telephone Hour" and "Sing Along With Mitch" due to their older viewership. The networks aimed to revamp programming, shedding its 1950s image and aligning it with contemporary American society. NBC, in particular, experienced success in the 1970s with shows like "Adam-12," "Rowan & Martin's Laugh-In," "Ironside," "The Dean Martin Show," and "The Flip Wilson Show."

In the 1970s, NBC started off strong with popular shows like "Adam-12," "Rowan & Martin's Laugh-In," "Ironside," "The Dean Martin Show," and "The Flip Wilson Show." The network introduced new shows, such as "NBC Mystery Movie," "Sanford and Son," "Chico and the Man," "Little House on the Prairie," "The Midnight Special," "The Rockford Files," "Police Woman," and "Emergency!" alongside continued success from established shows, "The Tonight Show Starring Johnny Carson" and "The Wonderful World of Disney." However, in the mid-1970s, NBC's ratings declined due to CBS airing "60 Minutes" against "The Wonderful World of Disney" and a failed attempt by new president Herbert Schlosser to draw younger viewers with expensive movies, miniseries, and specials, which also upset older viewers.

In the mid-1970s, NBC's attempt to draw younger viewers with expensive movies, miniseries, and specials backfired, as it failed to attract the desired demographic and upset older viewers. The new prime-time shows introduced in the fall of 1975 all flopped, with the exception of the innovative late-night comedy/variety show, Saturday Night (later renamed Saturday Night Live). In 1978, after NBC president Herbert Schlosser was promoted, the network brought in Fred Silverman from ABC to revive its ratings. However, Silverman's success was limited to shows like CHiPs, Barbara Mandrell and the Mandrell Sisters, Diff'rent Strokes, The Facts of Life, Real People, and the miniseries Shōgun.

Under Fred Silverman's leadership at NBC in the late 1970s, the network faced numerous failures with shows like Hello, Larry, Supertrain, Pink Lady and Jeff, The Krofft Superstar Hour, season six of Saturday Night Live, and The Waverly Wonders. These flops often lost in the ratings to series that Silverman had previously approved during his tenures at CBS and ABC. Concurrently, several long-standing NBC affiliates began switching to other networks in cities such as Atlanta, Bakersfield, Baltimore, Baton Rouge, Billings, Brownsville, Charlotte, Columbia (Missouri), Dayton, Decatur, El Dorado, Eugene, Fargo, Fort Smith, Green Bay, Indianapolis, Jacksonville, Knoxville, Marquette, and Minneapolis-St. Paul.

During Fred Silverman's time at NBC in the late 1970s, the network experienced numerous unsuccessful shows and lost affiliates to other networks. Many NBC affiliates, including stations in Atlanta, Bakersfield, Baltimore, Baton Rouge, Billings, Brownsville, Charlotte, Columbia (Missouri), Dayton, Decatur, El Dorado, Eugene, Fargo, Fort Smith, Green Bay, Indianapolis, Jacksonville, Knoxville, Marquette, and Minneapolis-St. Paul, switched to either ABC or CBS. ABC, which had become the #1 network during that time, attracted many of these stations away from NBC, while CBS gained affiliates like WBAL-TV, KERO-TV, KFSM-TV, KTVQ, KVAL-TV, KTVL, WRGB, and WTRF-TV. WATR-TV in Waterbury became an independent station and is now a CW affiliate (WCCT-TV). ABC had considered aligning with WBAL, but the station declined due to ABC's poor-performing evening newscasts. The specific stations mentioned include KSTP-TV (St. Paul), KTVL (Medford), KMID (Odessa), WMBB (Panama City), KOTA-TV (Rapid City), KGTV (San Diego), WSAV-TV (Savannah), WRGB (Schenectady), KSFY-TV (Sioux Falls), KCEN-TV (Temple), KLTV (Tyler), WATR-TV (Waterbury), and WTRF-TV (Wheeling).

During Silverman's tenure at NBC in the late 1970s, many of the network's affiliates, primarily VHF stations, switched to ABC or CBS. Some UHF stations, such as WAAY-TV, WATR-TV, KLAA-TV, and KERO, also defected, mainly due to the lack of VHF stations in their respective cities. Notable exceptions include WSB-TV and WSOC-TV, which remained with NBC under Cox Media Group ownership, while their sister station, WIIC-TV (later WPXI), stayed with NBC in Pittsburgh due to its weak position compared to CBS and ABC affiliates. The strained relationship between NBC and Westinghouse, which owned KDKA-TV, played a role in WIIC-TV's decision to remain with NBC.

During Silverman's time at NBC in the late 1970s, several affiliates, particularly VHF stations, left NBC for ABC or CBS. However, some UHF stations like WAAY-TV, WATR-TV, KLAA-TV, and KERO also switched. Notable exceptions include WSB-TV and WSOC-TV, which stayed with NBC. In cities with limited VHF options, NBC had to affiliate with UHF stations, some of which later became NBC O&Os. Smaller markets like Yuma, Arizona, had to wait years for another local NBC affiliate. Some stations, such as those in Baltimore, Columbia, Dayton, Jacksonville, Savannah, and Temple, eventually returned to NBC. However, others like El Dorado, Green Bay, and Bakersfield switched to Fox, CBS, and ABC, respectively. KOTA calls remain on a station owned by Gray Television in Rapid City. This shift occurred after President Jimmy Carter pulled the U.S. from a certain situation.

After the U.S. withdrawal from the 1980 Summer Olympics by President Jimmy Carter, NBC, which had invested heavily in broadcasting the games, faced significant losses. The network's future was threatened, as the cancellation of 150 hours of coverage disrupted the promotion of new fall shows and resulted in a projected loss of $170 million in advertising revenue. The situation was further exacerbated by internal criticism, with NBC's own promotional theme composer creating a parody song titled "Loud as a Peacock" that blamed NBC's struggles on then-president Fred Silverman. The song was aired on WNBC radio in New York, and although Silverman attempted to destroy all copies, it later resurfaced on the internet. As for Rapid City, the KOTA calls are now used by a station owned by Gray Television following these events.

Following the U.S. withdrawal from the 1980 Summer Olympics, NBC, which had heavily invested in broadcasting the games, faced significant losses due to cancellation of 150 hours of coverage. This threatened NBC's future and resulted in a projected loss of $170 million in advertising revenue. An internal critic, NBC's promotional theme composer, created a parody song titled "Loud as a Peacock" that blamed NBC's struggles on then-president Fred Silverman. The song was later widely distributed on the internet despite Silverman's attempts to destroy all copies.

In response to the parody, Saturday Night Live writer and occasional performer Al Franken satirized Silverman in a sketch titled "A Limo For A Lame-O". Silverman, who already didn't like Franken, was further displeased by the sketch, which ruined Franken's chance of succeeding Lorne Michaels as executive producer of SNL. Fred Silverman eventually resigned as entertainment president in the summer of 1981, and Grant Tinker, a highly regarded producer, became the president of the network while Brandon Tartikoff became the president of the entertainment division. KOTA calls are now used by a station owned by Gray Television following these events.

After Fred Silverman's resignation, Grant Tinker, a well-regarded producer and co-founder of MTM Enterprises, took over as network president. Brandon Tartikoff became the president of the entertainment division, inheriting a schedule with mostly aging dramas and few sitcoms. Tartikoff demonstrated patience with promising shows, like the critically acclaimed Hill Street Blues, which initially had poor ratings. Instead of canceling it, he moved the show to Thursdays, where its ratings improved significantly. This strategy was also applied to St. Elsewhere and Cheers. Despite the lower overall ratings of these shows, they attracted upscale adults aged 18-34, enabling them to generate ad revenue comparable to higher-rated competition. Although the network had moderate successes with Gimme a Break!, Silver Spoons, Knight Rider, and Remington Steele, its biggest hit during this period was The A-Team, which was the only program to rank in the Nielsen Top-20 for the 1982-83 season and climbed to fourth place the following year. KOTA calls are now used by a station owned by Gray Television following these events.

The text discusses how NBC, after a disastrous 1983-84 season with no successful new shows, found success with a late-night talk show hosted by David Letterman. The Cosby Show's popularity in 1984 led to a resurgence in sitcoms and boosted the viewership of Family Ties and Cheers, which had initially struggled. These shows, along with others like The Golden Girls, Miami Vice, and Night Court, helped NBC climb to second place in the ratings in the 1984-85 season and reach first place the following year.

In the context of the previous text, this summary highlights how NBC's strategic decisions, such as moving promising but low-rated shows to better time slots and taking risks on new shows, contributed to their eventual success and rise in the ratings. The text also emphasizes the importance of The Cosby Show in revitalizing NBC's sitcom lineup and leading to the success of other shows.

After their initial success in the mid-80s, NBC's upward trajectory persisted throughout the decade with the addition of popular shows like ALF, Amen, Matlock, L.A. Law, The Hogan Family, A Different World, Empty Nest, Unsolved Mysteries, and In the Heat of the Night. In 1986, Bob Wright took over as chairman of NBC. NBC made strides in technology by becoming the first network to broadcast in stereo in 1985. They also worked on mending their relationships with previously lost affiliates, such as Savannah, Temple, Columbia, and Jacksonville, as well as WOWT. In 1987, NBC introduced a syndication package for its owned-and-operated stations, titled "Prime Time Begins at 7:30," which included five weekly sitcoms produced by various production companies. In summary, NBC's strategic decisions, such as investing in new shows and restoring old affiliations, along with the impact of The Cosby Show, significantly contributed to their rise in ratings and eventual success.

NBC's "Prime Time Begins at 7:30" syndication package, launched in 1987, featured various productions like Marblehead Manor from Paramount Television, a sitcom about a mansion owner and his residents; She's the Sheriff by Lorimar-Telepictures, starring Suzanne Somers as a widowed county sheriff; an adaptation of You Can't Take It with You starring Harry Morgan; Out of This World by MCA Television, featuring a teenager with supernatural abilities; and a revival of We Got It Made by Fred Silverman for MGM Television. This package was part of NBC's strategic moves to boost their programming and expand their viewership.

In 1986, NBC introduced the "sitcom checkerboard" concept on KCRA in Sacramento, which involved airing five different sitcoms in a checkerboard pattern, including revivals like Mama's Family and It's a Living. This strategy aimed to draw viewers to NBC stations in the half-hour before prime time, capitalizing on the FCC's relaxation of the Prime Time Access Rule and Financial Interest and Syndication Rules. However, these sitcoms often underperformed in comparison to popular syndicated game shows like Wheel of Fortune, Jeopardy!, and Hollywood Squares. This checkerboard concept was a precursor to NBC's "Prime Time Begins at 7:30" syndication package launched in 1987.

In 1987, NBC's new sitcoms, including Marblehead Manor, We Got It Made, You Can't Take It With You, and She's the Sheriff, struggled in the ratings, often losing to popular game shows like Wheel of Fortune, Jeopardy!, and Hollywood Squares. Only Out of This World managed to last a few more seasons. In response, NBC decided to boost its in-house productions, planning to launch a series of half-hour dramedies. Additionally, they tested a new experimental sitcom lineup for Thanksgiving weekend, featuring Night Court, Beverly Hills Buntz, Family Ties, and My Two Dads. Concurrently, NBC's daytime lineup saw lower ratings due to the introduction of a new soap opera, Generations, set to air in spring 1988.

In the late 1980s, NBC made several changes, including merging NBC Enterprises with NBC-TV and Corporate Communications, integrating merchandising, foreign sales, guest relations, and studio tours into the new structure. NBC also started airing the Summer Olympic Games, beginning with the 1988 Seoul Games, and experienced great success with 17 series in Nielsen's Top 30 during the 1988-89 season. Despite ending their long-term partnership with Major League Baseball in 1989, NBC maintained their successful run with new shows like "The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air," "Blossom," and "Law & Order," coining the phrase "Must See TV." This period marked NBC's dominance in television ratings and popular culture.

In the early 1990s, NBC's success continued with the introduction of popular shows like "The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air," "Blossom," and "Law & Order," maintaining their "Must See TV" status. After a decade as NBC's President of Entertainment, Brandon Tartikoff transitioned to Paramount Pictures in 1991, having transformed the network from having no shows in the Nielsen Top 10 to having five. Warren Littlefield took over, facing initial challenges due to many Tartikoff-era hits concluding their runs. A notable controversy was the loss of David Letterman to CBS after Jay Leno was appointed as Johnny Carson's successor on "The Tonight Show."

After Brandon Tartikoff's departure from NBC in 1991, his successor, Warren Littlefield, faced initial difficulties due to several popular shows ending. A significant criticism was the loss of David Letterman to CBS after Jay Leno was chosen as Johnny Carson's successor on "The Tonight Show." However, Littlefield turned the situation around by introducing successful series like "Mad About You," "Wings," "Sisters," "Frasier," "Friends," "ER," and "Will & Grace." One of Tartikoff's late acquisitions, "Seinfeld," initially struggled but gained popularity and ended its run in 1998 as the leading show in Nielsen ratings, followed by "Friends" becoming NBC's top program.

Following the conclusion of "Seinfeld" and "Cheers" spin-off "Frasier" becoming a successful hit, "Friends" became NBC's most popular show, consistently ranking in the top five watched programs from its second to tenth seasons and reaching the number-one spot in the 2001-02 season. "Frasier" was also a critical and commercial success, often appearing in the Nielsen Top 20, although its ratings were somewhat overshadowed by "Friends," and it received numerous Emmy Awards. In the context of the previous text, this passage highlights how Warren Littlefield's new series, including "Friends" and "Frasier," helped NBC regain its footing after Brandon Tartikoff's departure and the loss of popular shows.

After "Friends" and "Frasier" became successful hits, NBC started labeling its powerful Thursday night lineup, specifically the comedies in the first two hours, as "Must See TV" in 1994. This branding, which later extended to NBC's comedy blocks on other nights, was part of the network's effort to regain strength following Brandon Tartikoff's departure and the loss of popular shows. During this period, NBC also began partnering with several stations affected by the 1994-96 broadcast TV realignment, a shift prompted by Fox's acquisition of NFL rights in December 1993.

In the mid-1990s, as NBC aimed to reestablish its dominance after Brandon Tartikoff's departure and the loss of popular shows, the network formed partnerships with various stations affected by the broadcast TV realignment. These stations, including WBAL-TV, WHDH, WCAU, KSHB-TV, WCBD-TV, WGBA-TV, WPMI-TV, and KHNL, were previously associated with Westinghouse Broadcasting, New World Communications, Allbritton Communications, and SF Broadcasting. Simultaneously, NBC's sports division, led by Dick Ebersol, secured broadcasting rights for three major professional sports leagues (NFL, MLB, and NBA), the Olympics, and Notre Dame Fighting Irish football. The NBA on NBC experienced significant success during this time, largely due to the Chicago Bulls' six championships led by superstar Michael Jordan.

NBC's NBA coverage, particularly due to the Chicago Bulls' success with Michael Jordan, thrived in the 1990s. However, a significant setback occurred in 1998 when NBC Sports lost the rights to broadcast AFC games to CBS, ending its 36-year association with the AFC and 59-year relationship with the NFL. This change happened after NBC's previous entertainment president, Warren Littlefield, left the network in 1998. His successors, Scott Sassa, Garth Ancier, and eventually Jeff Zucker in 2000, took over during this period of change and oversaw the development of new shows like The West Wing, Law & Order: Special Victims Unit, and Fear Factor. NBC experienced three entertainment presidents in three years following Littlefield's departure.

Following Warren Littlefield's departure in 1998, NBC saw a succession of entertainment presidents: Scott Sassa, Garth Ancier, and eventually Jeff Zucker in 2000. During this time, NBC lost its longstanding rights to broadcast AFC games, and CBS took over as the ratings leader in 2000. The following year, CBS moved its hit reality show Survivor to Thursday nights, posing a threat to NBC's nearly two-decade dominance on that night. Despite the success of Friends, Will & Grace, ER, and Just Shoot Me!, NBC's fortunes had begun to decline at the start of the 2000s.

After Warren Littlefield's departure in 1998, NBC had several entertainment presidents and faced a decline in ratings. Shows like "Friends," "Will & Grace," "ER," and "Just Shoot Me!" helped NBC maintain its lead on Thursday nights, but the loss of AFC games to CBS and the move of "Survivor" to Thursday nights posed a threat. NBC attempted to attract new viewers by airing select dramas in letterbox, but only saw a minor boost. They also lost broadcast rights for Major League Baseball to Fox and the NBA to ABC. However, NBC reclaimed the top spot in ratings for several years, with the exception of the 2002-2003 season when CBS briefly took first place.

Following the loss of NBA rights, NBC's main sports events were limited to the Olympics (including the Winter Olympics as of 2002), PGA Tour golf events, and a struggling Notre Dame football program, until it secured NHL rights in 2004. In 2001, NBC purchased Telemundo from Liberty Media and Sony Pictures Entertainment for $2.7 billion, outbidding CBS/Viacom. The merger was completed in 2002. In 2003, Vivendi Universal sold 80% of its film and television subsidiary, Vivendi Universal Entertainment, to NBC's parent company, General Electric, uniting the network with Vivendi Universal's assets, such as Universal Pictures, Canal+, and Universal Parks & Resorts. NBC Universal was then co-owned by General Electric (80%) and Vivendi (20%). This acquisition and merger aimed to strengthen NBC's position in the entertainment industry.

After NBC's acquisition of Vivendi Universal Entertainment in 2003, the network came to be co-owned by General Electric (80%) and Vivendi (20%). In 2004, Jeff Zucker was appointed as the president of NBC Universal Television Group, and Kevin Reilly became the new president of NBC Entertainment. However, NBC faced a challenging situation as three of its popular shows, including Friends and Frasier, ended their runs, and the network was left with few hit shows. The Friends spin-off, Joey, also experienced a decline in ratings during its second season. In an attempt to boost its primetime ratings, NBC introduced a week-long game show event, Deal or No Deal, in December 2005, which became a weekly series in March 2006. Nonetheless, the 2005-06 season was one of NBC's worst in three decades, with only one fall series, My Name Is Earl, surviving for a second season.

In the 2005-06 season, NBC's ratings dropped to the fourth position, following CBS, Fox, and ABC, due to intensified competition from cable TV, home videos, video games, and the internet. However, the 2006-07 season showed some improvement, with Deal or No Deal retaining its popularity and Heroes becoming a hit on Monday nights. Despite initial success, Studio 60 on the Sunset Strip was canceled due to a significant decline in viewership. Meanwhile, The Office and 30 Rock gained critical acclaim and modest success, winning the Emmy Award for Outstanding Comedy Series for four consecutive years. Additionally, NBC regained the rights to NFL's Sunday Night Football after eight years, which had previously been with ESPN.

In the 2006-07 season, NBC saw some improvement in ratings with shows like Deal or No Deal and Heroes, though still ranked fourth. The Office and 30 Rock gained critical acclaim. NBC regained NFL's Sunday Night Football rights from ESPN, but remained distant fourth. America's Got Talent, a summer hit, had high ratings, but NBC opted not to air it in spring, instead using it to promote fall shows. Kevin Reilly was replaced by Ben Silverman as president of NBC Entertainment, and Jeff Zucker became CEO of NBC.

During the 2008-09 season, NBC was unable to develop any successful new primetime shows, despite having the Super Bowl and Summer Olympics as platforms for promotion. The shows "Heroes" and "Deal or No Deal" experienced a decline in ratings and were eventually canceled, although "Deal or No Deal" was revived in syndication. The sitcom "Parks and Recreation" managed to secure a second season following a short first season. In a 2009 interview, Jeff Zucker, then CEO of NBC, expressed his doubt in NBC's ability to become the top-rated network in prime time. Ben Silverman departed from the network, and Jeff Gaspin took over as president of NBC Entertainment. In 2009, Comcast announced its intention to acquire a 51% controlling stake in NBC Universal from General Electric.

In 2009, GE bought Vivendi's 20% stake in NBC Universal using funds from Comcast's planned acquisition of a controlling interest in the company. The 2010 Winter Olympics, broadcast by NBC, saw a 21% increase in ratings compared to the 2006 Games, but was criticized for repeatedly airing footage of a fatal luge crash. Despite this, NBC was still expected to lose $250 million in ad revenue due to the high cost of acquiring TV rights. The 2009-10 season ended with only two scripted shows - "Community" and "Parenthood" - and three unscripted shows still on the air, as NBC struggled to improve its fourth-place position in prime time ratings.

In 2010, NBC renewed "The Jay Leno Show," "Community," "Parenthood," "Minute to Win It," and committed to airing "The Tonight Show with Conan O'Brien" in prime time. However, shows like "Heroes" and "Law & Order" were canceled. This move, criticized by industry executives, marked NBC as the first major network to broadcast the same program in a weeknight prime time strip. Despite the 2010 Winter Olympics' improved ratings, NBC was expected to lose $250 million in ad revenue due to high TV rights costs, and the network continued to struggle in prime time ratings.

NBC's decision to move "The Jay Leno Show" to prime time in 2010 was met with criticism from industry executives, who argued that it would damage NBC's reputation for airing quality dramas and hurt its local affiliate stations' late-evening newscasts. After announcing the cancellation of shows like "Heroes" and "Law & Order," NBC attempted to shift "The Jay Leno Show" to a later time slot and adjust its late-night lineup accordingly. However, this change had minimal impact on the network's ratings, which continued to struggle despite the success of "NBC Sunday Night Football." By 2012, the shows that replaced "The Jay Leno Show" in the 10:00 p.m. time slot drew lower ratings than the show did during its prime time run.

In 2012, shows taking the 10:00 p.m. slot had lower ratings than "The Jay Leno Show" had in 2010. Comcast, a cable provider and multimedia company, announced a majority interest acquisition in NBC Universal from General Electric that year, with Steve Burke becoming CEO of NBCUniversal and Robert Greenblatt replacing Jeff Gaspin as chairman of NBC Entertainment. Jeff Zucker stepped down as CEO upon the merger's completion. NBC struggled with ratings, cancelling all new fall programs by season's end, except for the midseason legal drama "Harry's Law." However, they found a hit in the reality singing competition series "The Voice" in 2011.

In 2011, NBC mostly transitioned to an HD schedule, excluding the Qubo-leased Saturday morning slot (which they later withdrew from in 2012). The 2011-2012 season was challenging, but some successes included the highest-rated Super Bowl broadcast to date and a successful Monday night lineup with "The Voice" and "Smash," propelling NBC to third place in the 18-49 demographic, ending an 8-year streak in fourth place.

The 2011-2012 season saw NBC finishing third in the 18-49 demographic, but most shows didn't achieve high ratings and NBC ranked fourth in total viewership. In the fall of 2012, NBC increased its sitcom lineup, leading to a first-place ranking in the 18-49 demographic. However, midseason ratings dropped, placing NBC fifth, even behind Univision. The 2012-2013 season ended with NBC in third place, as only three new dramas continued for a second season. Additionally, NBC Sports relocated its operations to Stamford, Connecticut in 2013.

In the 2013-2014 season, NBC's production of Football Night in America moved to Stamford, Connecticut, while the network enjoyed success with shows like The Voice, Chicago Fire, Sunday Night Football, and new hits like The Blacklist and Hannibal. The 2014 Winter Olympics also contributed to a ratings boost, making NBC the top network in the 18-49 demographic for the first time since 2003-04 and improving its total viewership to second place. However, the 2014-2015 season was less successful, with only one of the eight new series, The Mysteries of Laura, getting renewed for a second season.

In the 2014-2015 season, NBC introduced eight new shows, but only one, "The Mysteries of Laura," was renewed for another year. Despite this, the network's existing series, such as "The Blacklist," remained popular, even though viewership decreased after its shift to Thursdays. The Super Bowl XLIX attracted a record number of viewers, keeping NBC in the top position for the 18-49 demographic and second place in total viewership. The 2015-2016 season was also successful for NBC, thanks to the well-received new drama "Blindspot" and the launch of the second Chicago franchise installment, "Chicago Med," both of which received early second-season renewals.

In the 2015-2016 season, NBC launched the second Chicago franchise installment, "Chicago Med," which was successful and renewed early for a second season. Thursday nights remained challenging, with the cancellation of "Heroes Reborn" and "The Player," but "Shades of Blue" thrived and was renewed. In comedy, "Superstore" premiered with decent ratings and was renewed, while "This Is Us" debuted in the 2016-2017 season, receiving critical acclaim and renewal for two more seasons. However, "The Blacklist: Redemption" spin-off did not perform well.

In the 2016-2017 season, "The Blacklist" maintained moderate ratings, but its spin-off "The Blacklist: Redemption" failed to take off. NBC expanded the Chicago franchise with "Chicago Justice," and "Superstore" and "The Good Place" performed well. "The Wall" also premiered with modest ratings and was renewed. The 2017-2018 season saw the successful return of "Will & Grace" and the premiere of "Ellen's Game of Games," while "The Titan Games," "Manifest," "Songland," and "New Amsterdam" debuted in the 2018-2019 season, all of which were renewed. However, "The Village" and "The Enemy Within" only lasted one season.

The COVID-19 pandemic in 2019-2020 disrupted NBC's programming, leading to the postponement of the 2020 Summer Olympics and a drop in ratings. However, NBC rebounded and regained its position as the top-rated network in 2022. The pandemic had a significant impact on NBC's programming and ratings, but the network was able to recover.

In the context of the previous text, this summary explains how NBC's dominance in the 2010s was affected by the COVID-19 pandemic, which caused a major disruption in the network's programming and resulted in a drop in ratings. Despite this setback, NBC was able to recover and regain its position as the top-rated network in 2022. This summary retains the proposition that the pandemic had a negative impact on NBC's ratings, but also highlights the network's resilience and ability to recover.
